Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 10:25PM aprilgirl1 wrote: I also had a second opinion, although both were pretty equal.  I ended up choosing the larger, cancer center as the surgeon is a breast surgeon vs.  a general surgeon who does a lot of breast cancer surgeries.  I know it is a difficult time right now, you are dealing with the shock and sorrow of a diagnosis and now have to find the perfect doctor... Post a mesage here "anyone in Tampa, Florida?!" and I would ask around my community.  I am fairly new to my location but was able to find a few woman that had finished treatment in the last couple of years. By the way, my cancer was caught on a routine mammogram, so I was immediately scheduled with that hospital breast oncology team.  I had my MRI, genetic tests etc. done and was looking for a 2nd opinion.  I brought all of the path reports from the original hospital (they actually transferred the records) and chose the 2nd opinion.  So, continue with your appts - and look for a 2nd.  You may end up staying at your original place.  I am sure in my case either would have been fine. Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: 2nd Opinions & Recommendations mln8428 mzmiller99

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2009 06:05PM aprilgirl1 wrote: I, like all of you it sounds like - could not feel a thing.  I was a DDD with dense, at times lumpy breasts.  I had two team meetings for my treatment - both times the whole team (4 at one and 5 at another) felt my breast.  NONE of them could feel the 1.6cm tumor even knowing where it was.  They contibuted that to the size of the breast along with the fact that they said the tumor was small and not hard as it was "early".  I had a lumpectomy and then a bilateral reduction.  I would also have liked to know what the $#@ tumor felt like but I guess I will do SBE and rely on mammograms and ultrasounds for peace of mind.
Posts.Title: for large-busted women... admom thegoodfight

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2011 08:29AM - edited Oct 13, 2011 08:54AM by aprilgirl1 Kelly, my kids were 9 and 11.  We sat them down, and told them that I had been diagnosed with breast cancer.  My youngest blurted out "but there's no cure" and I told them that although that is true, it is considered treatable.  I also told them that we would know more after I had surgery, and at that point develop a plan.  My  husband and I reassured them that their daily life would really not change that much with the exception that friends moms may be picking them up from activities more often, and I may need more rest.   As Marial mentioned, I also emailed their homeroom teachers and school counselors, just so they would know in case either kid seemed "off" or upset. edited to add:  Good luck!  Keep it simple, as you learn information.  Let us know how you are doing!
Posts.Title: how do I tell my kids spunkyboobster Miller1353

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2011 12:46AM aprilgirl1 wrote: Posy, you have had great information posted on this thread.  I  just wanted to add that I had an ultrasound and MRI before I had my lumpectomy.  Both of those tests estimated my tumor to be between 2 and 3 cm, and it ended up to be 1.6cm.  I think recently, oncologists stopped getting as worked up about the size of the tumor, and look at all of the factors (grade, hormone status, her2 neu status, etc).  Yes, you want the results of the scans - more information you have, the better.  As the previous posters have said, you will get thru this.  Please keep us posted on how you are doing!
Posts.Title: Coping with the wait for the Stage TectonicShift Beeb75

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 04:21AM aprilgirl1 wrote: Love the husbands answer to clean underwear!  Sounds like you are on the road to recovery.  I didn't have a drain - don't know why.  I think you will feel progressively better - when can the drain come out?
Posts.Title: January Lumpectomy Lories Lories

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 10:33AM aprilgirl1 wrote: lemonjello - love that name by the way...I am 44, and had a lumpectomy - will do radiation after my chemo ends.  In addition, I was theoretically healthy - not on any medication at the time of my diagnosis, so aren't dealing with exactly your issues. That said, I would think your cardiologist would have an opinion.  Lumpectomy is a pretty easy recovery, although still requiring general anestethia (how DO I spell that?).  I am not sure is a mastectomy will be a longer surgery, with a more difficult recovery or not.   You have a 2nd opinion on March 5th - the MRI results should give you more clarity with what you are dealing with.  I would make an appt. with both Cardiologist and Kidney doc (Nephrologist?) to see what impact either/both surgeries have on you - if any. Hopefully, someone who has been there, done that will see your questions and respond.  Meanwhile, go see your other docs - with all of us getting bc I would think they have dealt with this before. Good luck with this! Susan

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 08:01AM aprilgirl1 wrote: CMF is a type of chemo.  It is often referred to as Chemo "lite" and is easy to tolerate.  ACT is a much stronger chemo - the down side is that it has more side effects.  I think they are very different but I am no oncologist.  My oncl. said that CMF was the one for me - the rest were too much for my personal case. There is a CMF thread under the "help me through treatment" section on here.  PM me if you have specific questions!

I don't what else to say except that we are all here for you, hopefully the scans will be easy to tolerate and hope you get some very good news about kicking this to the curb like you did the bc. Posts.Title: Horrible News re Swollen Groin Node mshalto mshalto

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2011 02:18PM aprilgirl1 wrote: In general, most people do not have severe pain.  I had two surgeries (lumpectomy and later a bilateral reduction and margin clearing surgery) and did not need the vicondin prescribed.  Radiation was very painful by the 4th week in my case.  I followed all of the docs directions with the cream, etc. and was also using the silvadene cream when it was necessary.  I did take vicondin at that point, and it helped.  My skin did not "break" but was seriously burned - I did not take any days off.  Had I needed the boost at the end, they would have made me take a break.  The techs could not believe how burned I got.   My friend is really fair and had no issues.  I am olive complexed and generally don't sun burn so go figure! Good luck with radiation - I'm sure you will be like most and sail through it.

Good luck

Posts.Title: Keeping One Breast as a Diagnostic Tool? Alaina blondie45

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 08:23AM aprilgirl1 wrote: Karen- first of all, positive thoughts from me to you regarding your sugery.  Your surgical choice has nothing to do with systemic recurrence, I hope you understand that.  That is what chemo, herceptin, tamoxifen etc, is for. I agree with the previous posters.  Your anger is misguided - you, of course can do what you want, but you are young with very young children.  Her2+ I believe will automatically up your oncotype score, which will probably put you into the "must have chemo" area.  THERE IS A REASON FOR THAT.   Chemo is not the end of the world.  It is very doable.  3 cm is on the larger side.  That does not mean that you are node positive.  I am 44, and node negative.  My sister (whom I trust) is in the medical field and she was ADAMENT that I do chemo, even with no node involvement.  My oncotype came back high intermediate, so I started chemo and really am doing well with it. I would suggest you do get a second opinion.  I have a feeling they will concure with your original oncologist. By the way, I have not read about the 1cm tumor size indicating cells in the blood stream, but I have read that negative nodes is not 100% guarantee.  There is no test for cancer cells in the blood stream - until it gets really advanced.  They use the lymph nodes as the guide and assume that if it is in the nodes, it is in the blood stream.  If it is not in the nodes, hopefully it isn't in the blood stream.  Another reason why I chose chemo. Karen, I am 44 and also so healthy it would make you shocked!  I feel great.  I have not been on the pill, and have none of the risk factors.  sh#& happens.  I feel lucky this was caught. Hang in there. We are all there with you, and will support you no matter what decision you make.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 08:13AM aprilgirl1 wrote: You will find other women on the November 2009 or December 2009 chemotherapy threads that are having this chemo at the same time as your mom.  She, or you will find a lot of support and information on how to deal with side effects on those threads. Best wishes to you both!
Posts.Title: The Red Devil cdelaughter chainsawz

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 08:16PM aprilgirl1 wrote: Karen - thank you so much for checking back in, and I am really happy that your surgery went well, and your nodes are clear.  That is great news.  So HAPPY that you are getting a second opinion. You have been in my thoughts.  This is your personal choice, as you know. I think chemo is much less scary than you write about.  I also think your best chance at no recurrence is to hit it hard the first time - especially as young and healthy as you are. I also did a ton of research, as I imagine most of us do.  For me knowledge is power. Keep healing, build up your strength, and keep learning about the specifics of your case. I promise you that it gets better.  I felt similar to you before I had a plan and started chemo.  I am about half way done and feel great.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 11:56PM aprilgirl1 wrote: I live on Bainbridge Island, and had my treatment at SCCA, surgery at UW.  I am very, very happy with my oncologist and surgeon, but I heard my oncologist is on a medical leave right now so won't refer you to her.  Like most of the women have said, both Swedish and Seattle Cancer Care Alliance are top notch medical/cancer centers.  The Seattle thread is in the chemotherapy forum and is titled "Crazy, Sexy Cancer in Seattle".  It is a great group of women, and you can also get first hand knowledge on the many doctors in this area.  Pam - LOVE your new photo - you look great!

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 05:01PM aprilgirl1 wrote: yunlee - I would also advise chemo, depending on the oncotype score.  My score was 23.  I did CMF chemo, which is considered easier to tolerate.  It also leaves the heavier chemos as options - if you have a recurrence.  Once you have your oncotype score, you will be able to assess your options better.   Your age and grade do indicate a recommendation of chemo - as Pure wrote, 90% vs. 98% is a big difference.
Posts.Title: Stage IIA with no Chemo yunlee72 Janina

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 06:45PM aprilgirl1 wrote: If insurance won't cover the oncotype, Genomic Health will help you appeal (they are the oncotype lab).  I thought most insurance in the US  cover it  - as it is now standard of care, but I could be wrong. Mine covered it.  They did not cover the BRAC testing, or zometa for stage 1, so don't cover everything my onc. would like.  I did the BRAC testing anyway - which is not a bad idea for you to do as you are young.  I think talking to your onc. again sounds like a good idea.  A second opinion is never a bad idea either.
Posts.Title: Stage IIA with no Chemo yunlee72 Janina

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 12:53AM aprilgirl1 wrote: Skhartley - My score was 23, I was 44 and I did CMF chemo.  I think you will find that the younger you are and pre menopausal - the oncologists are more likely to recommend chemo...they were a bit antsy with my age of 44 so I can imagine your age of 38 has them doing the same. I also had two opinions, and think a second opinion is great!  At this point we all just have to make the decision that works for us.   In my case,  chemo was easy to tolerate and I am happy with my decision.  Good luck to all - I am thankful for the oncotype (so many of us can skip chemo) and thankful for BCO - it is so great to be able to have these discussions!

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 04:28PM aprilgirl1 wrote: mahalahondre  - I had an ultrasound first, then an ultrasound guided biopsy which was a core needle biopsy.  My biospy didn't really hurt too much - they did give me a numbing shot first.  I also got an MRI but not until after my biopsy results were positive.  I would go ahead with the biopsy.  I did get two opionions but they were after I got the biopsy results that were cancer, so the opinions were for surgery/oncology etc. etc.  I wonder if you are getting an ultrasound and a biopsy at the same time.  Calcifications can be benign - I would want to know now what exactly they are seeing - and hope it is benign. They can mammogram, ultrasound or MRI but a biopsy is the real info. Good luck and let us know how it goes.
Posts.Title: Breast Calcifications azcamm Makratz

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 07:56PM aprilgirl1 wrote: Glendora - I think that is great.  I was also treated at a large NCI center (Seattle Cancer Care Alliance - part of UW and Fred Hutch)  and had a lumpectomy.  My surgeon got 1mm clear, so did a re-excision after I finished chemo.  It was all clear.  Just because the margin is not clear the first time does not mean that they have left a large amount of cells.  I also had a bilateral reduction at the same time - taking 30-40 % of all tissue, which was clear.  I happened to be a DDD - so welcomed the reduction. I had two surgical consults - the first said she would absolutely refuse to do a mastectomy, and the surgeon I went with said it was completely overkill in my specific case, but would do as I wished. I think each case is very unique, but I also believe that one lumpectomy that needs better margins no longer = immediate mastectomy.  Your case (and mine) are good examples of that. Good for you -  and it sounds like your surgeon in Visalia is great too - interested in learning vs. ego issues. I don't know when your surgery at Stanford is scheduled, but good luck with it!
Posts.Title: STANFORD U RECOMMENDS THREE LUMPECTOMIES B4 MASTECTOMY Glendora celia088

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 12:43AM aprilgirl1 wrote: number5 - okay, I know how hard this is.  Take a deep breath.  Here is one way to look at it - the biopsy could have made some scar tissue, which can show up as calcifications.  The MRI does not show calcifications, but it would show a tumor.  So, perhaps they are doing the MRI to rule out a tumor.  I have read that calcifications alone do not always mean cancer.  As Idaho said, 80% of the time biopsies are benign.  If the MRI shows something, then they will do a biopsy. I had an ultrasound once calcifications were found - are you having an ultrasound?  My calcifications were in a spiculated pattern - which, of course, was not a good sign - now I know that! Please let us know how the MRI is - hang in there.
Posts.Title: Here I go again-now an MRI! number5 number5

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2009 09:55PM aprilgirl1 wrote: If you look at the forum leaf recommended "depression, Anxiety, and PTSD" there is a thread called regret.  I just read it, and one of the posters said that she is bi-polar.  Maybe you could send her a private message?  Really and truly you are at the hardest part of the cancer experience - waiting for information and testing.  Once you know exactly what you are dealing with and have a plan it gets easier.   hang in there!
Posts.Title: I am also bipolar mj50withca aprilgirl1

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 12:52AM aprilgirl1 wrote: panfutas - this is the hardest part.  The MRI is good to make sure nothing else "lights up" and the biopsy will tell you exactly what that mass is.  I wish your biopsy was sooner, just so you could get the waiting over with earlier.  As far as time goes, I know I felt like a time bomb when I was waiting but I was assured that a week or even more wouldn't make a difference. As far as your question, what happens next depends on your biopsy results.  It could be benign, in which case I don't know what they do.  If it is cancer, then the biopsy tells you exactly what type, hormone receptors and grade and then you make plans to have it surgically removed and Staged where they also check your lymph nodes. 1cm is small, and in my case my mass looked 2-3 cm on ultrasound and was actually 1.6cm. I would try to get a sooner appt, and if you can't, just try to remember that you have caught this now which is good, and will deal with it. I am sending you positive thoughts that this is benign.   Susan

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 01:43PM aprilgirl1 wrote: Kate - I also needed a reexcision for clear margin (2mm clear on one side).  I opted for a bilateral reduction at that time as I was a DDD.  Re-excision clear, and I am very happy.  The reduction was my silver lining, so to speak as I had been wanting one for years.   I had SNB with the original surgery, 3 nodes taken - all clear.  I also had DCIS in there, which I think is pretty common - they described my tumor are being surrounded by dcis with the idc in the middle.  Sorry, I can't help you with grade interpretation.  Hang in there!   It sounds like you are in good hands.

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 01:07AM aprilgirl1 wrote: jwaldher - so sorry that you are in our club.  I thought I was young at the age of 44 when I was diagnosed!   You are not the first young woman that I have come across on these boards, but most are late 40's on up.  There is an organization called young survival coalition (www.youngsurvival.org) that was designed for young breast cancer survivors like yourself.  I know there are others on the boards.  You will find a lot of support, and good information here on what to expect with surgery and the other specifics of your treatment.  I wish you the best.  You might want to check out the surgery/mastectomy threads for info on bilaterals.  It sounds like you have a great attitude, which helps us get through these times, right?!

Posts.Content: May 7, 2009 11:55AM aprilgirl1 wrote: ameron - I had NO symptoms whatsoever.  I was 44 (now 45) and had some calcifications picked up on my annual mammogram - non digital mammogram at that.  I do have dense tissue, so the tech told me at that time I should go next year to the actual breast center to have a digital.  Needless to say, I was called in for additional films to the breast center where I had digital mammograms followed by an ultrasound. I felt great, have always been healthy, and have none of the risk factors.  I will be done with chemo in the end of June and still feel pretty good. I still feel lucky this was caught by mammogram as I read that some tumors aren't. I met with two cancer teams to get opinions.  8 cancer specialists could not find my tumor on breast exam and I could never feel it either. Good luck with this - hope you find that this is benign!
Posts.Title: OTHER SYMPTOMS??? ameron zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 11:17AM aprilgirl1 wrote: Marcic - I was not in the same situation, but wanted to respond and welcome you to bc.org.  Sorry you are here, but know that you will find support, great information and some wonderful friends here.  From what I have learned on here, radiation is often how they treat margin issues. I don't know of any other way - are they doing an oncotype to determine chemo, or was your tumor insitu?   Hang in there - this will be behind you.  You may want to repost your topic on the radiation forum and there should be a group starting radiation roughly the same time as you - those threads were really helpful to me at the time. Take care of yourself!
Posts.Title: after lumpectomy 1 positive margin found marcic aprilgirl1

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2010 01:36AM aprilgirl1 wrote: Isla - the 10 year old that was diagnosed last year is named Hannah, and she lives in So. Calif.  If you do a search on "10 year old with BC" you will find plenty of coverage.  I initially saw her parents post on here, as they were SHOCKED that this was happening....eventually it was on the today show, Katie Couric National News, and even our local news picked it up.  I believe she had triple negative BC and yes, was pre-puberty.  You can also search on here - there was a couple of threads  on this - one started by her father, and one by another member.  I know she had surgery, chemo and I believe is doing well! Poeticrevolver - your question is a good one.  Good that you tested negative for the BRAC gene - although we all know there are most likely other genetic markers that haven't been identified yet.  I, have a 13 year old daughter - and I had my first abnormal mammogram at 44 when diagnosed.  I will encourage my daughter to start checking in her early thirties at the latest.  I also agree that right now with your diagnosis I would not get your girls to over focus on what this means to each of them.  Like Isla wrote,  most women I know with BC have no family history - and that included me.  I made sure my daughter knew that I am the only woman in our family (of MANY women) to get BC so most likely it is not hereditary AND in my case early detection found it. I agree with much of what Collette wrote - vitamin D is a big issue for increase in cancer, breast cancer and other health issues (I too live in the Pacific NW).  I was deficient and my entire family now supplements.  We already did organic milk, meat and most of our veggies, so that didn't really help us out.  I also have avoided foods with corn syrup - and still do for the whole family. My sincere hope is that we will find a CURE for this in our lifetimes - and that will protect our kids. I think that we will find more tests like the oncotype, and BRAC to pinpoint and treat each of our cases as individually as possible.  My oncologist told me that breast cancer is really like 6-8 completely difference diseases. I'm sorry you went thru hell getting diagnosed, and hope that you are doing okay with your treatment plan.
Posts.Title: Concerned about my children, any advice would be appreciated! poeticrevolver eileen1955

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 12:00AM aprilgirl1 wrote: GregH - I think you are right on track.  However, I started buying organic milk and usually bought organic or non hormone added chicken when my kids were born (11 and 9).  Here I am with BC! As I have hormone positive breast cancer, I will only buy organic meat and dairy from now on.  I am doing conventional treatment but saw a naturopathic doctor who said organic meat and dairy only.  I also had my vitamin and minerals tested and am low in Vitamin D. There is no one in my family that has had breast cancer, or cancer in general (we get heart disease). I do think there are some environmental factors and personally Vitamin D plays a role in my case (I live in Seattle). Good luck - don't know what type of  breast cancer your wife has, but this board is great. Susan

Posts.Title: why do I need chemo after lumpectomy with clean nodes aaronali12 jotti

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 12:42PM - edited Jan 9, 2011 12:57PM by aprilgirl1 Wow - Kansakay you are coming across as very defensive.  Plenty of stage 1 women do not need chemo.  Plenty do.  Each of us have very individual cases - as much as the docs categorize us into stages and grades - as a scientist you would know that it is not nearly this simple. My oncotype was 23 - middle ground - so I happily did chemo.  44 at diagnosis, and with two young kids and as others have posted, would be much happier with the knowledge that I did chemo as the gray oncotype category is not known at this time if chemo really helps.  I really don't care. For me, I know I did all I could with the info. I had to decrease my risk of recurrence.  I feel GREAT.  LOOK GREAT!  Had no side effects at this point and don't expect to have any.  I did CMF which is very "popular" in my region.  It was very easy for me to tolerate. I was put into chemopause, and the pause stuck, so I am on femara with quarterly estrogen checks by my oncologist.  With femara I am lucky that I don't have any noticeable side effects and have been on it for a year now. Like most of the women on here, I have no family history, and my only risk factor was having my first child at 32.   My point is, Kay - I think we all support your decision.  For you this is what made sense.  The sense I get from  your posts on this thread is that you believe those of us who are stage I and did chemo "drank the Koolaid" because we are somehow less intelligent, or misinformed - or basing our decisions on FEAR not FACTS.  This could not be farther from the truth - I am very informed and very intelligent, as I believe most of us are.  I most often question authority, had multiple opinions and many doctors in my family that reviewed my case. The question was - "If you were stage I, did you get chemo?????" and you can see many of us did, and many of us didn't- as I said,and you know it would be wrong to not use the oncotype to help us to make our decisions. Hoping that all of you waiting for the oncotype get a low score!
Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 06:05PM aprilgirl1 wrote: This is a hard decision for all of us.  I think along the lines of the poster Rose G.  From all I have read and been told my multiple cancer doctors - lumpectomy/rad has the same survival rate as mastectomy.  I don't know your wifes specifics i.e. er/pr+m her2 status etc.  If she is es/pr + then taking a hormone surpressant will do a lot for her long term - according to the stats. As she is not brac1/2 positive that supports a lumpectomy as well.  I chose a lumpectomy.  I also had a 4mm satellite of my original tumor (1.6cm).  They have a 1mm clear margin on the dcis, so I need a re-excision.  I am really happy, even with a re-excision that I had only the lumpectomy.  Frankly, I am less worried about recurrence in the breast and more worried about systemic recurrence.   I think we all need to support our own decisions.  Have you checked out Dr. Susan Love's website or book?  I think there is information on there to help make this decision. This is directed to Just Saying - My dcis was picked up on the ultrasound and MRI.  I have an acquaintance that has three small DCIS tumors picked up my mammogram, so I disagree that DCIS is not screenable BUT I will agree that I hear of cases often (of course on this site!) that were missed, or picked up after the fact and that completely freaks me out! I think if it makes sense, is easy to remove and you get clear margins, lumpectomy is the way to go.  No one can fault those who go for the mastectomies either - especially due to multiple tumors, close to chest wall, or too extensive.  Good luck with this! Either way, it will work out for you.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 03:23PM aprilgirl1 wrote: Nellie - I just had my "one year after diagnosis" oncology check up.  They take a LOT of films during the mammgram -and it was all clear.  My blood work was reviewed during the onc. appt - except for the vitamin D and FSH which took a week to get back.  The onc. nurse called me with those results.  I can assure you that with a history of BC they took a lot of extra films and time with reviewing my mammogram and told me that the radiologist said that it looked good.  I got a form letter a week later stating it was clear.  You will do fine, and it is a relief to have it over. Meece - I agree about going outside without sunscreen.  I live in the beautiful, but perpetually gray Northwest so at this time of year it is very inconsistent to get direct sunlight!  I have also read that up here in the NW the suns rays are too far in the winter so even on sunny days we don't absorb enough vita D (don't really know if it is true - can't believe everything on the internet, right?!).   I would think that in California you could get enough sun to soak up the D.  Keep on top of it - it seems like the oncs. think it is important. Kanthony - welcome - sorry you are here, and Nicole is so right - the waiting is the hardest part.  Once all the results come in and the "plan" is in motion, it is easier.  Not the best way to spend the holidays (I had my lumpectomy last year on 12/1 and was waiting for the oncotype all December - got the results right after xmas).

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 01:18PM aprilgirl1 wrote: I was on Cobra when I was diagnosed, and it ended this February.  I am stage 1, but was also concerned about the pre-existing conditions, pricing etc. of our next insurance. Here is what I found out.  As long as you have continuous coverage, have not missed any cobra payments and start your new policy immediately the insurance company can not use pre-existing conditions against you.  I think they also have to give you a fair price for your policy. If you do not have continuous coverage, then they can deny insurance and also use pre-existing conditions against you.  So the important thing is to not let your coverage drop, or have missed payments. We stayed with Regence on an individual plan.  The cost was relatively the same, as well as what they cover.  They do provide you with a "certificate" or letter of coverage, which is very important.  We picked the most expensive Regence plan as they had the best prescription coverage.  Honestly I did not research too many other insurance companies as I found the whole process scary and overwhelming. Good luck with this!  This whole process has given me and my family a whole new understanding of the health care issues in the US.
Posts.Title: My COBRA runs out in 6 months lorrhaw MaryNY

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 02:41PM aprilgirl1 wrote: I think Alpal may be correct that staying with the same coverage may be important to avoid pre-existing conditions, but I also did it to try to keep things simple - I know my current team of doctors are in the plan.  However, I do think that some of the Hippa laws from 1996 were created to protect patients like us. I did not have to fill out any of the medical forms - as I had that certificate of coverage.  Without it, I would have had tons of additional paperwork regarding medical history of my whole family. The one thing that is KEY is that you do not drop in coverage at all during Cobra.   Either way, Cobra and now our individual coverage is expensive.  As my husband was laid off right before my diagnosis, and has started his own company  it has been very stressful to say the least.  I did call my insurance company to inquire about individual plans after Cobra eneded about 6 months before our termination date just to find out what they would say aboutpre-existing conditions.  Call your insurance company (I did it without stating my name or policy number) and see what they say.  It gave me a lot of peace of mind. I hope that all of you in this situation are covered as I was - it was very seamless (although just started in March).

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 08:07PM aprilgirl1 wrote: movinOn, sorry that you are joining us.  I was diagnosed in early November, and am 44.  You are so young - have you taken the genetic brac1/2 test?  My doctor really encourgage me to as they consider me young for bc - and I have no family history.  That info can really impact your surgical decision. As I tested negative, and after the Mammogram, ultrasound, and MRI only had the one tumor, I chose to do a lumpectomy.  My tumor was small and in a good place to surgically remove.  My doctors also recommended lumpectomy.   It is really a personal decision.  Mastectomies are often necessary, but in my case it wasn't and in my opinion, if you are do not test positive for the brac1/2 gene your case is pretty straight forward too. Best of luck to you - keep posting!

My cancer was found by a routine annual mammogram - which I did because I was supposed to but honestly thought it was an inconvenient waste of time as "it did not run in my family".  Well, here I am - thank goodness I had my mammograms! Mine was non palpable so who knows when it would have been detected and what stage it could have grown to. This is the most ridiculous medical guideline I have heard.  Most of the women I know are under 50 and being diagnosed with no "risk factors". Yes, my life matters more than the $200 a  year a mammogram will cost.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 01:50PM aprilgirl1 wrote: Happy Saturday - Nicole - I was taking 4,000iu of vitamin D3 for the past 4 months.  A year ago when I was diagnosed my level was 23.  Last week at my oncologist appt my blood was tested and is 55.  My onc. wants it at 50, so now I am to take 400iu daily.  What is your level?  How long are you or have you been taking the 50,000 weekly?  I am also taking vitamin C.  Now that I know chemotherapy put me into menopause at 44 I will add curcumin - a supplement of tumeric that has some anti cancer component from what I have read.  I also take a multivitamin (that included the 400iu of D3) and  2 baby aspirins along with my femara. So far so good on the femara, although it has only been a week.  I have been busy writing emails to the @#$% task force - so maybe the femara is causing mood swings???  (jk)  Niclole - I read your post about the oncotype and would be irritated that my onc. didn't order it.  Did you have chemo?  If you did they probably figured the test wasn't necessary.   Oh - I mentioned my tumor was non palpable which just means none of the doctors could feel it by hand - and this is knowing where it was.  Seriously, 10 of them tried - I had 2 opinions and both had residents along with the surgeon, onc. and radiation onc.  I felt a wee bit like an animal at the zoo, but it was for a good reason.   I know so many women that have found their tumors and mammograms didn't.  We need better diagnostic tests! Valerie - congrats on the good news!  I don't visit this thread enough, but you are a great group of women - and this is a wonderful thread! April

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 03:06PM aprilgirl1 wrote: Merilee, Jancie and all - I agree - I am taking the time to think about the choices I make and people in my life.  We have a ton of house guests - like two weekends a month it seems that we have visitors.  All fun, but a ton of work - and it barely slowed down during chemo and rads.  Some friends called last week and said they wanted to come for a visit next week.  I just called them and told them that it wasn't going to work out.  I need time with my family to just chill out and relax. It is okay for me to say no - which I have learned I don't do enough of!  My new mantra is to not commit to anything until I have had 24 hours to think about it, check all schedules and talk to my husband.  THEN - if the answer is no, I say "that is just not going to work for me". I too have no family history and don't fit the risk factors (except low vitamin D which I think plays a part) and here I am.  I had a stressful couple of years prior to diagnosis - moving states, kids having a hard time adjusting etc. and think that contributed.  I also agree that it seems to be the perfect storm of a concoction - stress, environment,  possible unknown genetics etc. that must make our immune systems fail - this is just my opinion. Let's just add that the stress of having cancer, treatment choices and also the treatments are a lot of stress for us AND our families.  I can not WAIT for 2010.  2008/2009 really was awful.
Posts.Title: Stress could put you at risk for cancer??? Hindsfeet bonnie1jean

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2012 10:31AM aprilgirl1 wrote: Jayme - your oncologist should order an oncotype test on your tumor.  That really helps in this process of deciding chemo, and the risk of not having chemo.   When I was diagnosed 3.5 years ago, standard of care with a tumor over 2cm chemo was recommended.  I'm not an oncologist, but it would seem that you have a few cancer things going on. They can't predict the effectiveness of chemo based on tumor size, so I'm not sure what your are referring to when you said "the Surgeon said the effectiveness of chemo at 2.5 is really on the fence".Maybe the surgeon was referring to 2cm as the point of which they automatically recommend chemo? I think it's a great idea to get a second opinion but also get the oncotype test done.  They take a tissue sample from the tumor and send it to Genomic Health to have the test performed.  It's possible due to the total size of 5cm they won't do the oncotype, but that I don't know. My tumor was 1.6cm, and my oncotype score was 23.  I did chemo, and handled it fine - happy I did it and it's behind me. I'm happy for you that your surgery is behind you and once this decision is made, you will feel soo much better.  Good luck and hugs to you!
Posts.Title: Chemo or no Chemo? Help! Jayme33 Jayme33

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 11:31PM aprilgirl1 wrote: ziva - I had a lumpectomy with 1mm clear margin.  For 2mm clear margin I had an additional lumpectomy AND a bilateral reduction (at the same time).  My surgeon did refer to this as oncoplastic surgery.  It was a lift, reduction and also took care of the majority of the lumpectomy scar (tumor at 11 0'clock).  6 weeks later I had radiation.  My breasts still look very similar after rads - one of course is a bit TAN (was very burned, which of course faded).  I am really happy with the outcome and would say it is my silver lining in the bc ride.  I have also heard that the breast can develop a divet after the lump. swelling goes down, but have not experienced that. Both my  breast surgeon and plastic surgeon say that oncoplastics is the wave of the future for all bc patients. Good luck with this!
Posts.Title: Oncoplasty Reconstructionn after lumpectomy zivagirl aprilgirl1

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 08:55PM aprilgirl1 wrote: ebarb - the oncotype dx is a test that, like talbrig13 said - is done on a tissue sample from the tumor that they removed in surgery.  The surgeon sends the tumor sample to Genomic Health in California and they do this test.  Your score helps you and the oncologist decide if chemo will be a benefit to you.  The test was initially done on node negative women but I believe has expanded to included women with up to three positive lymph nodes. This test has helped many women safely avoid chemo - when they have very low oncotype scores.  As talbrig13 pointed out, Genomic Health has a pretty good website. Check it out!
Posts.Title: onconotype test? ebarb aprilgirl1

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 10:58AM aprilgirl1 wrote: LeesaAnn - My oncotype was 23, and I had two opinions.  I was 44, and that was a significant factor for the oncologists in recommending chemo.  They gave my benefit as higher than 2-3 %, more like 6%.  I felt that same as Deanna.  Due to my oncotype score in the gray area (no lvi) my oncologists prescribed CMF which is a long chemo cycle, but very tolerable.  Many of my bc friends had 4 cycles of T/C and did fine.  I think it's always a good idea to get a second opinion, and I'm glad they are reviewing it with the tumor board.  I hated that they gave me so much input in this decision. Good luck with this- let us know how you are doing!
Posts.Title: Onco 22 and must decide on Chemo LeesaAnn mdg
